item.title: China’s Rare Earth Exports Recover Ahead of US Trade Talks
item.description: Chinese exports of rare earths, a group of 17 minerals at the center of a trade dispute with Washington, rose 23% in May from the previous month, according to customs data on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rogers

item.title: China’s Copper Boom Tested as Miners Wield Bargaining Power
item.description: The unrelenting expansion of Chinese copper processing capacity over the past few years has now become a global headache, as smelters scramble to secure the ore they need to produce the vital industrial metal.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie, Winnie Zhu

media:content.media:description: Worker handles copper plates in a copper electrolysis plant at the Zijinshan mine, operated by Zijin Mining Group Co., in Longyan, China, on Monday, Sept. 23, 2024. Zijin Mining is vying with the largest Western producers for a spot among the top ranks, even as geopolitical tensions worsen.

item.title: Asian Stocks Gain on Trade Talks, Meta Lifts Tech: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian stocks rose on optimism about US and China trade negotiations Monday, while positive jobs data in the world’s largest economy eased recession fears.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

media:content.media:description: Global Market Strategist Anna Rathbun discusses the impact of a rare earths deal between the U.S. and China, and how the feud between Elon Musk and President Trump shook up Tesla shares. She speaks with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.”

item.title: ‘Most-Unloved Bonds’ Turn Routine US Auction Into Crucial Test
item.description: Global investor pushback against long-term government debt is turning what normally would be a routine US bond auction into one of the most anticipated events on Wall Street this week.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick, Michael Mackenzie

item.title: Elliott Calls for Sumitomo Realty Improvement in Rare Letter
item.description: Elliott Investment Management is calling for Sumitomo Realty & Development Co. to improve shareholder returns and corporate governance, saying the Japanese real estate developer’s stock is worth 40% more than its current value.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Du

item.title: Oil Holds Ground Ahead of Fresh Round of US-China Trade Talks
item.description: Oil steadied after a weekly surge as a renewed round of US-China trade talks offered the potential for reduced global tensions.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

item.title: LA Immigration Clashes Escalate for Third Day (Correct)
item.description:
Demonstrations over US immigration raids intensified for a third consecutive day in the Los Angeles area, with thousands of protesters clashing with security forces outside a downtown federal detention center. Bloomberg’s Alicia Caldwell reports on the latest developments.
(Corrects headline to remove reference to Trump considering Marines deployment. The video has also been edited to remove an anchor's description of Trump's comments.) (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Foreigners Extend Korea Bond-Buying Streak to Longest Since 2023
item.description: South Korean bonds are enjoying the longest streak of buying by foreigners since April 2023, as investor appetite for local assets improve with the new administration in place.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom

item.title: JSDA Said to Probe Brokerages on Unsuitable Japanese Bond Sales
item.description: The Japan Securities Dealers Association is probing brokerages on inappropriate bond selling practices such as overstating to issuers how much demand there is for their debt, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga

item.title: Julius Baer Sees Consumption Revival in India Taking Stocks to Record High
item.description: Julius Baer Group is expecting Indian stocks to hit a new high in the second half of the fiscal year, as domestic consumption recovers.
item.dc:creator: Alex Gabriel Simon, Diksha Rajput

item.title: US, China to Resume Trade Talks With Focus on Rare Earths
item.description: The US and China are set to resume trade negotiations in London on Monday in a bid to further defuse tensions over rare-earth minerals and advanced technology following a phone call between leaders Donald Trump and Xi Jinping last week.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Rare-earth magnets in Tianjin, China. Photographer: Doug Kanter

item.title: Indian Central Bank's Jumbo Rate Cut Could Supercharge IPO Pipeline
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: OPEC+ Quota Hikes Yet to Deliver Oil Surge, Morgan Stanley Says
item.description: The OPEC+ alliance may be boosting oil-production quotas at a significant pace in a push to restart idled capacity, but that shift has yet to translate into big gains in actual output, according to Morgan Stanley.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin

item.title: Keep the Portfolio Tilt Toward Risk, Lombard Odier's Lee Says
item.description: Lombard Odier's Homin Lee says investors should "keep the portfolio tilt toward risk" as latest developments suggest that "we're still in the middle of the deal making phase in the Trumpian trade policy." Lee discusses his outlook for global equities on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Wall Street Touts India Options for Market Insulated From Trump
item.description: India’s equity rally may have stuttered recently, but Wall Street banks are now doubling down on the world’s fifth-largest stock market, this time focusing on derivatives.
item.dc:creator: Savio Shetty

item.title: Activist Retail Investors Take On Korea’s Corporate Laggards
item.description: South Korea’s small investors are trying to shake up the country’s creaky corporate landscape.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung at his inauguration in Seoul on June 4. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea's Retail Investors Push for Change Among Corporate Laggards
item.description: South Korea’s small investors are trying to shake up the country’s creaky corporate landscape. Gathering on social media platform like KakaoTalk and dedicated shareholder apps, their aim is to give a jolt to Korea’s famously undervalued stock market. Bloomberg TV's Shery Ahn explains. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Steadies After Two-Day Loss Ahead of US-China Trade Talks
item.description: Gold was steady — after losing almost 2% over the previous two sessions — as another round of US-China trade talks offered hope trade tensions between the two largest economies can be eased.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: Quant Firm’s $1 Billion Code Is Focus of Rare Criminal Case
item.description: The prosecution of a trader could define how a quant algorithm can become stolen property and have a huge impact on Wall Street’s talent war.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch

item.title: Five Key Charts to Watch in Global Commodity Markets This Week
item.description: Oil watchers who have been anticipating a glut now have the numbers to back it up as global inventories climb. The world is spending billions for power infrastructure to meet soaring demand — and that’s going to need a lot of engineers. China hosts the world’s biggest solar convention this week where the mood might be gloomy. And silver is shining brighter.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Josh Saul, Alex Longley

item.title: BYD Unleashes an EV Industry Reckoning That Alarms Beijing
item.description: The price war engulfing China’s electric vehicle industry has already sent share prices tumbling and prompted an unusual level of intervention from Beijing. The shakeout may just be getting started.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Chunying Zhang

media:content.media:description: The BYD Han. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: US Inflation to Tick Higher as Tariffs Reach Consumers
item.description: US consumers probably saw slightly faster inflation in May, notably for merchandise, as companies gradually pass along higher import duties.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at a grocery store in Scottsdale, Arizona.

item.title: National Guard Troops Line up in Front of LA Protestors
item.description: National Guard troops arrived in Los Angeles on Sunday under orders from President Donald Trump, escalating a showdown with California leaders who say the federal deployment is politically driven and unnecessary. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Lone Star’s Novo Banco Is Said to Get Bids From BPCE, CaixaBank
item.description: Lone Star’s Portuguese lender Novo Banco SA attracted two bids from French banking group BPCE and CaixaBank SA of Spain, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Swetha Gopinath, Jorge Zuloaga, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: A customer uses an automated teller machine (ATM) at a Novo Banco SA bank branch in Lisbon, Portugal, on Friday, March 14, 2025. Home prices in Portugal, one of Europe’s hottest property markets, are expected to continue rising in 2025 on the back of increasing foreign demand and lackluster supply, according to DBRS Morningstar.

item.title: Venezuela Plans a 50% Fuel Hike as It Braces for Revenue Slump
item.description: Venezuela’s government is laying the groundwork for a 50% hike in fuel prices at the pump as it braces for a decrease in revenues after US oil major Chevron and other oil firms halted work in the country.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Zerpa

media:content.media:description: A Petroleos de Venezuela SA (PDVSA) gas station in Puerto La Cruz, Anzoategui state, Venezuela, on Monday, May 22, 2023. Venezuela’s Oil ministry published oil and gas reserves for years 2019 through 2022, according to a decree in the official gazette dated May 9.

item.title: US Seeks Deal in London on China Rare Earth Flows, Hassett Says
item.description: US negotiators will aim to restore the flow of critical minerals when they meet their Chinese counterparts for a new round of trade negotiations Monday in London, a top economic aide to President Donald Trump said.
item.dc:creator: Vincent Lee

media:content.media:description: Various rare earth minerals on display in a showroom at the Baotou Jiangxin Micro Motor Technology Co., in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China, on Thursday, June 1, 2023. Traditionally a center for coal and steel, the city is marketing itself as the “World’s Green Silicon City,” to lure factories that process the metal needed for semiconductors with low-cost, renewable power.

item.title: Colombian Presidential Hopeful Shot at Rally in Bogotá
item.description: Colombian presidential candidate Miguel Uribe Turbay remains in a critical condition after an assassination attempt on Saturday that recalled the political violence that roiled the nation in the 1980s and 1990s. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: National Guard troops stationed along Alameda Street in Los Angeles, CA
item.description: Protests in parts of Los Angeles continue after immigration officials conducted several raids and arrested dozens on Friday. Federal officials say about 2,000 National Guard troops have been deployed to the area. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: How Will Private Equity Change Big Law?
item.description: Big law is going through a transformation as private equity sees the investment potential in law firms. For an industry built on tradition and ethics, how will non-lawyers change the business? (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Yield Hunters Fuel a $331 Billion Wave of Emerging Bond Sales
item.description: Strong demand from yield-hungry investors is driving a surge in developing-world bond sales as borrowers race to secure financing ahead of any further wobbles in global markets.
item.dc:creator: Vinicius Andrade, Zijia Song
